results.title: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
results.creator_credit: Marlene Rubuntja and Sally M Nangala Mulda
results.brief_description:
First Peoples were forcibly moved from their lands into designated camps by European colonists from around 1880 onwards. As a result of the ongoing displacement of First Peoples, Amoonguna was established as a government reserve 21kms from Mparntwe (Alice Springs) in 1963. Known as town camps today, reserves like Amoonguna make up the Alice Springs Aboriginal housing associations. These town camps are home to many artists who are extremely proud of their communities. English is often the third language of Amoonguna residents with the major language groups being Arrernte (pronounced Arenda), Warlpiri and Pitjantjatjara.

Mparntwe is a place where government policy and intervention in First Peoples communities has distinct and obvious implications. The Australian media often portrays this part of the nation negatively, without showing the historical narratives at play or the strength, beauty and talent that comes from the Central Desert. At the centre of the exhibition Two Girls From Amoonguna, is the animated video work Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls, which reminds audiences that Mparntwe is filled with joy and laughter. From camping and travelling to town to finding bush tucker, this place is home.

Tangentyere Artists and Yarrenyty Arltere Artists are akin to community hubs. Not only are they gallery and commercial spaces, but they are also places for young ones to learn and spaces for important community discussions.

For Sally M Nangala Mulda (Arrernte and Southern Luritja) and Marlene Rubuntja (Arrernte and Western Arrarnta), their art centres reflect their artistic practices. The soft sculpture, sewing and bush dyeing seen in Marlene’s works are synonymous with Yarrenyty Arltere Artists. Tangentyere artists like Sally are renowned for figurative paintings, which are often autobiographical and depict scenes in and around Mparntwe. These centres provide culturally safe places for artists and community. With the success of both artists, they have become prominent figures in their communities and teach many young people within their kinship structure. Intergenerational knowledge sharing is integral to First Peoples’ ways of life – you can even hear the voices of the artists’ nieces and nephews in the animated work.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marlene Rubuntja and Sally M Nangala Mulda
results.description:
Life in the Central Desert can be challenging, but it can also be breathtakingly beautiful. Two Girls From Amoonguna tells the intertwined story of Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja, from their childhood years to now as two of Australia’s leading artists, through paintings, sculptures and a newly commissioned animated video.

The animation Arrkutja Tharra, Kunkga Kutjara, Two Girls was inspired by a conversation between Sally and Marlene, held on the steps of the Sydney Opera House, where they reminisced about their shared childhood at the Amoonguna settlement, outside of Mparntwe (Alice Springs), in the early 1960s. Figures from Marlene’s soft sculptures and Sally’s acrylic-on-linen paintings come to
life, depicting life as they know it to create a portrait of two friends and the communities that made them.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.

results.title: Untitled Goose Game
results.creator_credit: Jake Strasser, Michael McMaster, Nico Disseldorp, Stuart Gillespie-Cook and House House
results.credit_line:
Gift of House House Pty Ltd.
Acquired via the National videogame collecting partnership between ACMI, the Powerhouse and the National Film and Sound Archive.
results.material_description: Digital videogame and archive of material relating to the creation of Untitled Goose Game
results.brief_description: Untitled Goose Game is developed by Australian developer House House. Players take on the role of an annoying goose, waddling around an old English Town to create mischief and chaos. By completing a to-do list, players gradually unlock access to more areas of the town. Untitled Goose Game received widespread acclaim since its launched in late September 2019, with critics praising its gameplay and humour. It was named the D.I.C.E. Game of the Year and received a BAFTA Games Award for Best Family and Social game in 2020. It is available for PlayStation, Xbox, Nintendo Switch, PC and Mac.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Jake Strasser, Michael McMaster, Nico Disseldorp, Stuart Gillespie-Cook and House House
results.description: It’s a lovely morning in the village and you are horrible goose. Untitled Goose Game is a slapstick-stealth-sandbox, where you are a goose let loose on an unsuspecting village. Make your way around town, from peoples’ back gardens to the high street shops to the village green, setting up pranks, stealing hats, honking a lot, and generally ruining everyone’s day.

results.title: Fugitive II
results.material_description: interactive software, video, motion controller, projection, computer, cameras and infra red flood lights
results.brief_description:
Fugitive II is the second iteration of the interactive digital video installation Fugitive (I), developed in 1996-7 at CMU, Pittsburgh USA and ZKM, Karlsruhe, Germany by Simon Penny, with the assistance of Jamie Schulte and Andre Bernhardt.

The question ‘what is Fugitive II’ may be answered from two directions. As a piece of interactive media research, Fugitive (I+II) attempt to move beyond a simplistic state-machine model of interactivity in which raw instantaneous location of the user triggers events. Fugitive responds to the ongoing behaviour of the user.

Fugitive (I+II) attempt to remove the levels of abstraction and encoding common to most interactive paradigms. Users interact in Fugitive with no special clothes or headgear, no input devices and no training. Fugitive responds to the natural embodied expression and dynamics of human users. It models a more convivial kind of human-computer interaction. Theoretically, Fugitive has much in common with situated, embodied and phenomenological critiques of conventional Artificial Intelligence approaches.

The imagery in Fugitive II speaks to the conflicted nostalgia of the expatriate. The movement of the user undoes the original cinematography: for instance, the moving projected image puts the frames of a pan back on the wall at angles relative to each other that correspond to the original arc of the camera. In so doing, FugitiveII falteringly, fragmentally, reconstructs a virtual recreation of a place, only to be disrupted, deconstructed, or to collapse, due to user movement. FugitiveII speaks to the impossibility and the folly of dwelling in memory.

results.title: The Platypus
results.creator_credit: Betti Wood, Concept Films of Australia and Pilgrim Films
results.brief_description: Animated Aboriginal dreamtime legend of the creation of the platypus with live action at the beginning and end of the film. Narrated by Ron Haddrick.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Betti Wood, Concept Films of Australia and Pilgrim Films

results.title: Serious undertakings
results.creator_credit: Helen Grace, Erika Addis and Stunned Mullett Productions
results.brief_description: The film explores montage techniques with playful and complex effects. Through the film’s five separate segments, themes, images and sounds recur and clash in unexpected ways. The myths from Australian cultural history - of pioneers, mateship and rugged (male) individualism - are dismantled as created truths and manufactured history. Features Stephen Leeder, Marilyn Allen, Robert Alexander, Nicholas Enright.

results.title: The Landscape architects; Fire down below
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
“The Landscape architects” David Bellamy looks at how First Nations peoples learned to tame the countryside without becoming farmers, and at what sort of diet they enjoyed. “Fire Down Below” David Bellamy looks at the secrets of survival of the Australian flora against the frequent fires which seek to destroy.

results.title: Pauses
results.creator_credit: Monique Schwarz, International Women's Year Committee and Melbourne State College
results.brief_description: Examines the lives of three successful women who are in their forties. Joyce Nicholson, a writer and business woman, Helen Laycock, a potter and Rosie Smith who runs a craft business. Each describe their work and their experiences as a wife and mother. A useful film discussion starter about woman’s role in Australian society.

results.title: The Golden Jubilee of the CRB: Victoria 1913-1963
results.creator_credit: Jim Stirling and Country Roads Board
results.brief_description: Depicts 50 years of progress in road and bridge construction in Victoria. The first survey made in 1913 showed that travel was hazardous on the hand-made roads. In 1916 the first all-weather road to Geelong was completed. Gradually isolated settlers and mailmen were able to travel in the country. Municipal co-operation was sought and aid given for road construction by machines. Recent work includes new concrete bridges, and the completion of a two-lane highway from Melbourne to Dandenong, all important to Victoria’s prosperity. During 50 years, motor registrations increased from 10,000 to 90,000.
results.title_for_label: The Golden Jubilee of the CRB: Victoria 1913-1963

results.title: Beyond the boom: metal mining in Australia
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Norman Castle, Australian Mining Industry Council and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: The evolution of mining in Australia from the first gold discoveries to the iron, nickel and copper developments of the 1960’s , its historic importance in national growth and economic stability and in the exploration and settling of much of Australia. The scope of modern mining and processing industries, exploration and prospecting, the growth of new towns and stimulation of regional development.

results.title: Australia's art of the Dreamtime: Quinkin country
results.creator_credit: Jim Needham and WIPB-TV, Ball State University
results.brief_description:
A documentary on the history of Australian First Nations peoples and their rock art in the Cape York Peninsula region of Queensland. The program explores not only the historical background of the rock paintings but theorises on the first arrival of First Nations peoples to this land and the formation of the landscape itself through archaeological, geological and palaeontological evidence.
During the 1950s Australian artist and author Percy Trezise went on a quest to locate the rock art around Laura in the Cape York region and through contact with First Nations elders and befriending First Nations writer, Dick Roughsey, he was eventually accepted as a “tribal brother”. In this program, Percy, using images from his own paintings, interprets First Nations Dreamtime stories, mythology and initiation ceremonies as represented by the rock paintings. He speaks of his own experiences and respect for First Nations peoples, their culture and their heritage. Voice over narration by Chris Schenkel. Note: Visual quality average - filmed on video camera. Arts 2002 and SBS Independent.
